# ✅ DbSeeder Implementation Complete - Testing Guide
## What Was Implemented
**Option 2 (Easiest)** - Modified `DbSeeder.cs` to: - ✅ Update existing issues without Priority → sets to 3 (Medium) - ✅ Seed 23 new service requests with dependencies (only if not already seeded) - ✅ Preserve existing Events/Announcements (no duplication) - ✅ Create Graph relationships for testing BFS traversal
---
## How to Test
### Step 1: Run the Application
```bash cd Municipal-Servcies-Portal dotnet run ```
**What Happens:** 1. Application starts 2. DbSeeder runs automatically (in `Program.cs`) 3. Old issues get Priority=3 if missing 4. 23 new service requests are seeded (if not already present) 5. Events/Announcements remain unchanged
---
### Step 2: Verify in Browser
1. **Open:** `http://localhost:5298` 2. **Click:** "Track Status" in navigation 3. **You should see:** 23+ service requests in the table
**Visual Verification:** - ✅ Requests showing different priorities (Critical, High, Medium, Low, Very Low) - ✅ Different colored priority dots (red, orange, blue, gray) - ✅ Various statuses (Pending, In Progress, Completed) - ✅ Realistic descriptions and locations
---
### Step 3: Test POE Data Structures
#### **Test 1: Binary Search Tree (BST) - O(log n) Lookup** 1. Click on any request ID (e.g., #1) 2. Details page should load **instantly** (uses BST Search) 3. Check console logs for "Retrieved request details" message
#### **Test 2: MinHeap - Priority Queue Sorting** 1. On Track Status page, click **"Sort by Priority"** button 2. Requests should reorder: - Critical Priority (1) at top (red dots) - High Priority (2) next (orange dots) - Medium Priority (3) middle (blue dots) - Low Priority (4) lower (gray dots) - Very Low Priority (5) at bottom (light gray dots)
#### **Test 3: Graph with BFS - Dependency Tracking** 1. Navigate to request details #21 or #22 or #23 2. Scroll to **"Related Requests (Dependency Graph)"** section 3. Should see related requests with links 4. Example: - Request #21 depends on: #1, #6, #7 - Request #22 depends on: #1, #21 - Request #23 depends on: #5, #7, #22
---
### Step 4: Verify in Database (Optional)
**Open database viewer or run:** ```bash sqlite3 municipal_services.db ```
**Then run verification queries:** ```sql -- See verify-seeding.sql file for all queries SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Issues; -- Should be 23+ SELECT Priority, COUNT(*) FROM Issues GROUP BY Priority; ```
**Or use the provided SQL file:** ```bash sqlite3 municipal_services.db < verify-seeding.sql ```
---
## Expected Results
### Priority Distribution: | Priority | Label | Count | Color | |----------|-------|-------|-------| | 1 | Critical | 3 | Red | | 2 | High | 4 | Orange | | 3 | Medium | 5+ | Blue | | 4 | Low | 4 | ⚫ Gray | | 5 | Very Low | 4 | ⚪ Light Gray |
### Status Distribution: - **Pending:** ~10 requests - **InProgress:** ~7 requests - **Completed:** ~6 requests
### Dependency Relationships: - **Request #6:** Depends on #1 (bridge depends on water main fix) - **Request #12:** Depends on #6 (transit depends on bridge) - **Request #21:** Depends on #1, #6, #7 (planning assessment) - **Request #22:** Depends on #1, #21 (road resurfacing) - **Request #23:** Depends on #5, #7, #22 (development area)
---
## Sample Service Requests Created
### Critical Priority (1): 1. **#1** - Water main break (InProgress) 2. **#2** - Gas leak at school (InProgress) 3. **#3** - City Hall server fire (Completed)
### High Priority (2): 4. **#4** - Playground equipment damaged (Pending) 5. **#5** - Power outage 150 households (InProgress) 6. **#6** - Bridge structural cracks (Pending) → **Depends on #1** 7. **#7** - Sewage backup 8 properties (InProgress)
### Medium Priority (3): 8. **#8** - Large pothole (Pending) 9. **#9** - Street lights not working (Pending) 10. **#10** - Tree branch hazard (Completed) 11. **#11** - HVAC malfunction (InProgress) 12. **#12** - Bus shelter damaged (Pending) → **Depends on #6**
### Low Priority (4): 13. **#13** - Trail signage faded (Pending) 14. **#14** - Parking meter broken (Pending) 15. **#15** - Monument maintenance (Completed) 16. **#16** - Stop sign obscured (InProgress)
### Very Low Priority (5): 17. **#17** - Flower planters (Pending) 18. **#18** - Bench paint chipped (Pending) 19. **#19** - Bulletin board outdated (Completed) 20. **#20** - Handrail loose (Pending)
### Complex Dependencies (2-3): 21. **#21** - Downtown assessment (Completed) → **Depends on #1, #6, #7** 22. **#22** - Street resurfacing (Pending) → **Depends on #1, #21** 23. **#23** - New development utilities (Pending) → **Depends on #5, #7, #22**
---
## Troubleshooting
### Issue: No new requests appearing **Solution:** Check if `DependenciesJson` is set on any existing issues. If yes, seeder skipped. Clear Issues table: ```sql DELETE FROM Issues; ```
### Issue: "Database is locked" **Solution:** Stop all running instances of the app, then restart.
### Issue: Dependencies not showing on details page **Solution:** 1. Check if Issue #21, #22, or #23 exist 2. Verify `DependenciesJson` column has data 3. Check browser console for errors
### Issue: Priority not showing correctly **Solution:** 1. Check `Priority` column in database (should be 1-5) 2. Verify ViewModels have `Priority` property 3. Check AutoMapper mappings
---
## Next Steps for Testing
1. ✅ **Run the app** - DbSeeder will auto-execute 2. ✅ **Navigate to Track Status** - See all 23+ requests 3. ✅ **Test BST** - Click any request ID for instant details 4. ✅ **Test MinHeap** - Click "Sort by Priority" button 5. ✅ **Test Graph** - View request #21, #22, or #23 details 6. ✅ **Verify dependencies** - See related requests in Graph section
---
## POE Data Structure Demonstration
### Binary Search Tree (BST): **Operation:** `GetRequestDetailsAsync(int id)` **Time Complexity:** O(log n) **Test:** Click request #15 → Searches BST in ~3-4 comparisons (instead of 15 linear)
### MinHeap (Priority Queue): **Operation:** `GetRequestsByPriorityAsync()` **Time Complexity:** O(n log n) **Test:** Sort by Priority → Extracts in order: 1→2→3→4→5
### Graph (BFS Traversal): **Operation:** `GetRequestDetailsAsync(int id)` → dependencies **Time Complexity:** O(V + E) **Test:** View #22 → BFS finds: #1, #21 (2 vertices, 2 edges)
---
**Status:** ✅ READY TO TEST **Next Action:** Run `dotnet run` and navigate to Track Status page!

# Search Functionality Implementation Summary
## ✅ What Was Implemented
### 1. **Service Layer (LocalEventsService.cs)** - ✅ **SearchEventsAsync method** - Filters events by name, category, and date - Uses `AsQueryable()` to build efficient database queries - Applies filters conditionally (only when parameters are provided) - Case-insensitive search using `StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase` - Returns filtered results asynchronously
**Key Features:** - Partial match for event name (e.g., "Clean" matches "Community Clean-Up Day") - Exact match for category - Date range filtering (start date and end date support)
### 2. **Controller Layer (LocalEventsController.cs)** - ✅ **Updated Index action** to accept search parameters: - `searchName` - Event name/keyword - `category` - Category filter - `date` - Date filter
**Logic Flow:** 1. Check if any search parameters are provided 2. If yes → call `SearchEventsAsync()` with filters 3. If no → call `GetUpcomingEventsAsync()` to show all events 4. Record the search for future recommendation tracking 5. Build ViewModel and return to view
### 3. **View Layer (Index.cshtml)** - ✅ **Form submission** using GET method - Form parameters match controller action parameters exactly - Preserves search values after form submission using `Context.Request.Query[]` - Category dropdown maintains selected value after search - Date input retains selected date
**Form Fields:** - `searchName` - Text input for event name/keyword - `category` - Dropdown populated from database categories - `date` - Date picker for filtering by date
**Buttons:** - "Search Events" - Submits the form with all filters - "Clear Filters" - Reloads page without any query parameters
### 4. **Enhanced UX (localevents.js) - OPTIONAL** - ✅ **Debounce functionality** - Delays search until user stops typing (500ms) - ✅ **Instant search** on category/date change - ✅ **Two implementation options:** - Option 1: Simple URL reload (currently active) - Option 2: AJAX fetch (commented out, ready to use)
## How It Works
### Step-by-Step Flow:
1. **User enters search criteria** in the filter form 2. **Form submits to `/LocalEvents/Index`** with query parameters - Example: `/LocalEvents/Index?searchName=clean&category=Community&date=2024-10-20` 3. **Controller receives parameters** and checks if any are provided 4. **Service layer queries database** with applied filters 5. **Results are returned** to the controller 6. **ViewModel is built** with filtered events, announcements, and categories 7. **View displays results** with search criteria preserved in form fields
### Example Searches:
``` - Search by name only: ?searchName=festival - Search by category: ?category=Community Events - Search by date: ?date=2024-10-20 - Combined search: ?searchName=clean&category=Community&date=2024-10-20 ```
## Code Comments Explained
All code includes detailed comments explaining: - **What each section does** - **Why it's implemented that way** - **How the data flows** - **What each parameter means**
### Key Comments Added:
**Service Layer:** - How `AsQueryable()` works - Why we use `StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase` - How `Contains()` vs `Equals()` differ - When the database query actually executes
**Controller:** - How parameter binding works from query string - Why we check for null/empty values - How the search is recorded for recommendations - What happens when no filters are provided
**View:** - How form submission works with GET method - How to preserve form values after submission - Why we use `asp-controller` and `asp-action` - How the "Clear Filters" button works
**JavaScript:** - How debounce prevents excessive API calls - Why we use 500ms delay - Difference between instant search and debounced search - Two implementation options (reload vs AJAX)
## ✅ Testing Checklist
- [ ] Navigate to `/LocalEvents/Index` - [ ] Enter a search term and click "Search Events" - [ ] Verify results are filtered correctly - [ ] Verify search term remains in the input field after search - [ ] Select a category and search - [ ] Verify category remains selected after search - [ ] Select a date and search - [ ] Verify date remains selected after search - [ ] Click "Clear Filters" - verify all filters are cleared - [ ] Test combined filters (name + category + date)
## What's Still Needed for Full Marks
This implementation covers the **Search Functionality** requirement. You still need:
1. ❌ **Stack/Queue for search history** (15 marks) 2. ❌ **Personalized recommendations** based on search patterns (30 marks)
The current implementation includes: - ✅ Search by name, category, and date - ✅ All required data structures (Dictionary, SortedDictionary, HashSet, PriorityQueue) - ✅ User-friendly presentation - ✅ Form state preservation - ⚠️ Search recording (stub only - needs full implementation for recommendations)

To complete the assignment: 1. Implement search history using Queue/Stack 2. Build recommendation algorithm based on user search patterns 3. Display personalized recommendations (not just first 3 events)

# Video Explanation Guide - Municipal Services Portal This document contains detailed explanations for key code sections to use in your video presentation. --- ## Prompt 1 — Search/Filter Logic ### SearchEventsAsync() Method Explanation **Location:** `LocalEventsService.cs` (Lines 146-183) #### What It Does: The `SearchEventsAsync()` method provides flexible, multi-criteria filtering for events using Entity Framework Core's powerful query capabilities. #### How It Works: **1. Start with a Queryable Collection:** ```csharp var query = _context.Events.AsQueryable(); ``` - Creates an IQueryable that allows us to build the SQL query dynamically - No database call happens yet - this is query composition **2. Apply Keyword Filter (Partial Match):** ```csharp if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(name)) { query = query.Where(e => e.Title.ToLower().Contains(name.ToLower())); } ``` - **Case-insensitive** partial match using `.ToLower()` - Searches in event titles (e.g., "yoga" matches "Yoga in the Park") - Only applied if user provides search text **3. Apply Category Filter (Exact Match):** ```csharp if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(category)) { query = query.Where(e => e.Category.ToLower() == category.ToLower()); } ``` - Exact match on category (e.g., "Community Events") - Case-insensitive comparison - Only applied if user selects a category **4. Apply Date Range Filter:** ```csharp if (startDate.HasValue) { var dateOnly = startDate.Value.Date; query = query.Where(e => e.StartDate.Date >= dateOnly); } ``` - Filters events FROM the selected date onwards - Uses `.Date` to ignore time component - Open-ended range (shows all future events from that date) **5. Filter Active Events Only:** ```csharp query = query.Where(e => e.IsActive); ``` - Ensures only active events are shown (soft delete pattern) **6. Execute Query Asynchronously:** ```csharp return await query.OrderBy(e => e.StartDate).ToListAsync(); ``` - **ToListAsync()** sends the query to SQL Server asynchronously - Orders results by start date chronologically - Non-blocking operation - UI remains responsive #### EF Core Magic: - All the `Where()` clauses are combined into a **single SQL query** - EF Core translates LINQ to SQL efficiently - Only the matching rows are returned from the database - Example SQL generated: ```sql SELECT * FROM Events WHERE IsActive = 1 AND LOWER(Title) LIKE '%yoga%' AND LOWER(Category) = 'health & wellness' AND CAST(StartDate AS DATE) >= '2025-10-20' ORDER BY StartDate ``` #### Key Benefits: ✅ **Flexible** - Any combination of filters works ✅ **Efficient** - Single database query, not multiple ✅ **Asynchronous** - Non-blocking UI ✅ **Type-safe** - Compile-time checking --- ## Prompt 2 — Recommendations ### How GetRecommendedEventsAsync() and RecordSearchAsync() Work Together **Location:** `LocalEventsService.cs` (Lines 186-267) #### The Big Picture: These two methods form a **personalized recommendation engine** that learns from user behavior to suggest relevant events. --- ### Part 1: RecordSearchAsync() - Tracking User Behavior **Location:** Lines 186-191 ```csharp public Task RecordSearchAsync(string? searchName, string? category, DateTime? date, DateTime? endDate) { _searchHistoryService.AddSearch(searchName, category, date); return Task.CompletedTask; } ``` #### What It Does: - Called every time a user performs a search - Captures three pieces of data: - **searchName**: Keywords typed (e.g., "farmers market") - **category**: Selected category (e.g., "Community Events") - **date**: Selected date filter #### Where It's Called: In `LocalEventsController.cs`: ```csharp await _localEventsService.RecordSearchAsync(searchName, category, date, null); ``` #### Storage Mechanism: - Stored in **session storage** (not database) - Maximum 10 recent searches tracked - Persists for 2 hours - Privacy-friendly - data stays in user's session --- ### Part 2: GetRecommendedEventsAsync() - Generating Recommendations **Location:** Lines 193-267 #### Step-by-Step Breakdown: **Step 1: Load Data Structures** ```csharp await LoadEventsIntoStructuresAsync(); var searchHistory = _searchHistoryService.GetSearchHistory(); ``` - Loads all events into memory-based data structures for fast access - Retrieves user's search history from session **Step 2: Fallback for New Users** ```csharp if (searchHistory.Count == 0) { return _upcomingEventsQueue.UnorderedItems .Select(x => x.Element) .OrderBy(e => e.StartDate) .Take(5) .ToList(); } ``` - If no search history exists, show next 5 upcoming events - Good for first-time visitors **Step 3: Analyze Search Patterns** ```csharp var categoryCounts = new Dictionary(); var searchTerms = new List(); foreach (var item in searchHistory) { // Track category frequency if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(item.Category)) { if (!categoryCounts.ContainsKey(item.Category)) categoryCounts[item.Category] = 0; categoryCounts[item.Category]++; } // Collect search keywords if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(item.SearchText)) { searchTerms.Add(item.SearchText.ToLower()); } } ``` - **Frequency analysis**: Counts how many times each category was searched - **Keyword collection**: Gathers all search terms used - Example: If user searched "Parks & Recreation" 3 times and "Community Events" 1 time, Parks & Recreation gets priority **Step 4: Find Most Popular Category** ```csharp var topCategory = categoryCounts.OrderByDescending(x => x.Value).FirstOrDefault().Key; ``` - Identifies the category the user searches most frequently - This becomes the primary recommendation driver **Step 5: Strategy 1 - Category-Based Recommendations** ```csharp if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(topCategory) && _eventsByCategory.ContainsKey(topCategory)) { recommended.AddRange(_eventsByCategory[topCategory] .Where(e => e.StartDate >= DateTime.Now) .OrderBy(e => e.StartDate) .Take(5)); } ``` - Uses the **Dictionary** data structure for O(1) lookup - Gets events from the most-searched category - Only future events - Takes up to 5 events **Step 6: Strategy 2 - Keyword-Based Recommendations** ```csharp if (recommended.Count < 5 && searchTerms.Any()) { var existingIds = recommended.Select(e => e.Id).ToHashSet(); var keywordMatches = await _context.Events .Where(e => e.IsActive && e.StartDate >= DateTime.Now && !existingIds.Contains(e.Id)) .ToListAsync(); var matchingEvents = keywordMatches .Where(e => searchTerms.Any(term => e.Title.ToLower().Contains(term) || e.Description.ToLower().Contains(term) || e.Category.ToLower().Contains(term))) .OrderBy(e => e.StartDate) .Take(5 - recommended.Count); recommended.AddRange(matchingEvents); } ``` - Kicks in if we don't have 5 recommendations yet - Searches for events matching user's **keywords** in: - Event title - Event description - Event category - Avoids duplicates using `existingIds` HashSet - Example: User searched "yoga" → recommends "Yoga in the Park" **Step 7: Strategy 3 - General Fallback** ```csharp if (recommended.Count < 5) { var existingIds = recommended.Select(e => e.Id).ToHashSet(); var fallback = _upcomingEventsQueue.UnorderedItems .Select(x => x.Element) .Where(e => !existingIds.Contains(e.Id)) .OrderBy(e => e.StartDate) .Take(5 - recommended.Count) .ToList(); recommended.AddRange(fallback); } ``` - Final safety net: fills remaining slots with general upcoming events - Ensures we always show 5 recommendations **Step 8: Return Results** ```csharp return recommended.Distinct().Take(5).ToList(); ``` - Removes any duplicate events - Guarantees exactly 5 or fewer recommendations --- ### Real-World Example: **User Behavior:** 1. Searches "yoga" → No category 2. Searches for "Parks & Recreation" category 3. Searches for "Parks & Recreation" category again 4. Searches "hiking" → No category **Analysis:** - `categoryCounts`: { "Parks & Recreation": 2 } - `searchTerms`: ["yoga", "hiking"] - `topCategory`: "Parks & Recreation" **Recommendations Generated:** 1. **Strategy 1**: Parks & Recreation Cleanup Day (top category match) 2. **Strategy 1**: Hiking Trail Grand Opening (top category match) 3. **Strategy 2**: Yoga in the Park (keyword "yoga" match) 4. **Strategy 3**: Community Town Hall (general fallback) 5. **Strategy 3**: Summer Festival (general fallback) --- ### Key Benefits: ✅ **Multi-strategy** - Combines category, keyword, and fallback approaches ✅ **Personalized** - Based on actual user behavior ✅ **Privacy-conscious** - Session-based, not tracked in database ✅ **Progressive** - Gets better as user searches more ✅ **Fail-safe** - Always shows relevant content even for new users --- ## Prompt 3 — View Binding ### LocalEvents/Index.cshtml Layout Explanation **Location:** `Views/LocalEvents/Index.cshtml` #### Model Binding: ```csharp @model Municipal_Servcies_Portal.ViewModels.LocalEventsViewModel ``` - The view receives a **LocalEventsViewModel** object - Contains three main collections: - `Model.RecommendedEvents` (IEnumerable) - `Model.Events` (IEnumerable) - `Model.Announcements` (IEnumerable) - `Model.Categories` (IEnumerable) --- ### Section 1: Recommendations Section **Lines 56-80** (approximately) ```csharp @if (Model.RecommendedEvents != null && Model.RecommendedEvents.Any()) {

Recommended for You

Based on your interests and search history

@foreach (var evt in Model.RecommendedEvents.Take(3)) { // Display recommendation cards }
} ``` #### How It Works: 1. **Null check**: `Model.RecommendedEvents != null && Model.RecommendedEvents.Any()` - Only shows section if recommendations exist - Prevents errors for new users 2. **Three-column grid**: `recommendations-grid` CSS class - Displays horizontally on desktop - Stacks vertically on mobile 3. **Top 3 recommendations**: `.Take(3)` - Shows only the top 3 recommendations - Service provides up to 5, view displays 3 4. **Dynamic category colors**: ```csharp var categoryColor = evt.Category.Contains("Community") ? "blue" : evt.Category.Contains("Utilities") || evt.Category.Contains("Parks") ? "green" : evt.Category.Contains("Cultural") || evt.Category.Contains("Culture") ? "orange" : "blue"; ``` - Color-codes badges based on category - Visual differentiation 5. **Bootstrap Icons**: ```html ``` - Professional calendar icon for dates --- ### Section 2: Two-Column Layout **Structure:** ```html

` for sidebar content 2. **Bootstrap Icons**: Megaphone icon for announcements ```html ``` 3. **Date formatting**: ```csharp @announcement.DatePosted.ToString("MMMM dd, yyyy") // October 15, 2025 ``` 4. **Compact cards**: Smaller cards that fit the sidebar --- ### How Data Flows to the View: **Controller → ViewModel → View** **In Controller (LocalEventsController.cs):** ```csharp var viewModel = new LocalEventsViewModel { Events = events, // Search results or all events Announcements = await _localEventsService.GetAllAnnouncementsAsync(), Categories = await _localEventsService.GetCategoriesAsync(), RecommendedEvents = await _localEventsService.GetRecommendedEventsAsync() }; return View(viewModel); ``` **In View (Index.cshtml):** - Receives the complete ViewModel - Accesses properties directly: `@Model.Events`, `@Model.Announcements`, `@Model.RecommendedEvents` - Razor syntax iterates and binds data --- ### Responsive Design: **Desktop (> 768px):** - Two columns side-by-side - Recommendations in 3-column grid **Tablet/Mobile:** ```css @media (max-width: 768px) { .content-layout { grid-template-columns: 1fr; /* Single column */ } .recommendations-grid { grid-template-columns: 1fr; /* Stack recommendations */ } } ``` --- ## Prompt 4 — Data Structures ### Complete Data Structures Overview in LocalEventsService.cs **Location:** Lines 13-18 --- ### 1. SortedDictionary> **Declaration:** ```csharp private SortedDictionary> _eventsByDate = new(); ``` **Purpose:** - Stores events **grouped by date** in chronological order - Automatically maintains sort order **How It's Used:** ```csharp if (!_eventsByDate.ContainsKey(ev.StartDate.Date)) _eventsByDate[ev.StartDate.Date] = new List(); _eventsByDate[ev.StartDate.Date].Add(ev); ``` **Performance:** - **Insertion**: O(log n) - uses Red-Black tree internally - **Lookup**: O(log n) - **Enumeration**: O(n) - already sorted **Real-World Benefit:** - Quickly find all events on a specific date - Iterate events in chronological order without sorting - Example: "Show me all events on October 20, 2025" **Data Structure Type:** Tree-based (Red-Black Tree) --- ### 2. Dictionary> **Declaration:** ```csharp private Dictionary> _eventsByCategory = new(); ``` **Purpose:** - Groups events by category for instant category-based lookups - Used heavily in recommendations **How It's Used:** ```csharp if (!_eventsByCategory.ContainsKey(ev.Category)) _eventsByCategory[ev.Category] = new List(); _eventsByCategory[ev.Category].Add(ev); // Later in recommendations: recommended.AddRange(_eventsByCategory[topCategory] .Where(e => e.StartDate >= DateTime.Now) .OrderBy(e => e.StartDate) .Take(5)); ``` **Performance:** - **Insertion**: O(1) average - **Lookup**: O(1) average - **Memory**: Efficient hash table **Real-World Benefit:** - Instant category filtering: "Show me all Parks & Recreation events" - Powers the category-based recommendation strategy - No database query needed for category lookups **Data Structure Type:** Hash Table **Example Data:** ``` { "Community Events": [Event1, Event2, Event5], "Parks & Recreation": [Event3, Event7], "Cultural Events": [Event4, Event6] } ``` --- ### 3. HashSet (Categories) **Declaration:** ```csharp private HashSet _categories = new(); ``` **Purpose:** - Stores unique category names - Automatically prevents duplicates - Powers the category dropdown filter **How It's Used:** ```csharp _categories.Add(ev.Category); // Automatically handles duplicates // In controller: var categories = await _localEventsService.GetCategoriesAsync(); ``` **Performance:** - **Add**: O(1) average - **Contains**: O(1) average - **Uniqueness**: Guaranteed **Real-World Benefit:** - Populate category dropdown with unique values - No duplicate "Community Events" entries - Fast membership testing **Data Structure Type:** Hash Set **Example Data:** ``` { "Community Events", "Parks & Recreation", "Cultural Events", "Government Meetings", "Public Safety" } ``` --- ### 4. HashSet (Unique Event Dates) **Declaration:** ```csharp private HashSet _uniqueEventDates = new(); ``` **Purpose:** - Stores all unique dates that have events - Could power a "dates with events" calendar picker **How It's Used:** ```csharp _uniqueEventDates.Add(ev.StartDate.Date); public async Task> GetUniqueEventDatesAsync() { await LoadEventsIntoStructuresAsync(); return _uniqueEventDates; } ``` **Performance:** - **Add**: O(1) average - **Contains**: O(1) average - **Uniqueness**: Automatic **Real-World Benefit:** - Highlight dates in calendar UI that have events - Quick check: "Are there events on October 25?" - Avoid showing empty date results **Data Structure Type:** Hash Set --- ### 5. PriorityQueue **Declaration:** ```csharp private PriorityQueue _upcomingEventsQueue = new(); ``` **Purpose:** - Stores upcoming events sorted by start date - Always gives next upcoming event first - Only contains **future** events **How It's Used:** ```csharp // During loading: if (ev.StartDate >= DateTime.Now) { _upcomingEventsQueue.Enqueue(ev, ev.StartDate); } // To get upcoming events: while (tempQueue.Count > 0) { result.Add(tempQueue.Dequeue()); // Gets earliest event } ``` **Performance:** - **Enqueue**: O(log n) - uses binary heap - **Dequeue**: O(log n) - removes minimum - **Peek**: O(1) - view next event **Real-World Benefit:** - Efficiently get "next N upcoming events" - Used in recommendation fallback - Always maintains priority order (earliest first) **Data Structure Type:** Min-Heap (Binary Heap) **Example Flow:** ``` Enqueue(Event1, Oct 20) Enqueue(Event2, Oct 18) // Goes to front (earlier date) Enqueue(Event3, Oct 25) Dequeue() → Event2 (Oct 18) Dequeue() → Event1 (Oct 20) Dequeue() → Event3 (Oct 25) ``` --- ### 6. Stack (Recently Viewed) **Declaration:** ```csharp private Stack _recentlyViewedEvents = new(); ``` **Purpose:** - Tracks recently viewed events - LIFO (Last In, First Out) - most recent at top - Could power "Continue browsing" feature **How It's Used:** ```csharp public void RecordEventViewed(Event ev) { _recentlyViewedEvents.Push(ev); // Limit stack size to 20 if (_recentlyViewedEvents.Count > 20) { var tempStack = new Stack(_recentlyViewedEvents.Reverse().Skip(1)); _recentlyViewedEvents = tempStack; } } public IEnumerable GetRecentlyViewedEvents(int count = 5) { return _recentlyViewedEvents.Take(count); } ``` **Performance:** - **Push**: O(1) - **Pop**: O(1) - **Peek**: O(1) **Real-World Benefit:** - Show "Recently Viewed" section - Quick access to events user looked at - Natural browsing history **Data Structure Type:** Stack (LIFO) **Example Flow:** ``` Push(Event A) Push(Event B) Push(Event C) GetRecentlyViewedEvents(2) → [Event C, Event B] ``` --- ### 7. List (Search History) **Location:** `SearchHistoryService.cs` **Declaration:** ```csharp public List GetSearchHistory() ``` **Purpose:** - Stores user's last 10 searches - Tracks search text, category, and date - Session-based storage **How It's Used:** ```csharp public void AddSearch(string? searchText, string? category, DateTime? date) { var history = GetSearchHistory(); history.Add(new SearchHistoryItem { SearchText = searchText, Category = category, Date = date }); // Keep only last 10 if (history.Count > MaxSearchHistory) { history.RemoveRange(0, history.Count - MaxSearchHistory); } } ``` **Performance:** - **Add**: O(1) amortized - **RemoveRange**: O(n) - **Iteration**: O(n) **Real-World Benefit:** - Powers recommendation engine - Analyzes user search patterns - Privacy-friendly (session-only) **Data Structure Type:** Dynamic Array (List) --- ### Summary Table: Performance Comparison | Data Structure | Insertion | Lookup | Use Case | Big-O | |---------------|-----------|---------|----------|-------| | **SortedDictionary** | O(log n) | O(log n) | Events by date, sorted | Tree-based | | **Dictionary** | O(1) | O(1) | Events by category | Hash table | | **HashSet (strings)** | O(1) | O(1) | Unique categories | Hash set | | **HashSet (DateTime)** | O(1) | O(1) | Unique event dates | Hash set | | **PriorityQueue** | O(log n) | O(log n) | Upcoming events | Min-heap | | **Stack** | O(1) | O(1) | Recently viewed | LIFO | | **List** | O(1) | O(n) | Search history | Dynamic array | --- ### Why These Structures Matter: 1. **Performance**: O(1) and O(log n) operations vs O(n) database queries 2. **Efficiency**: Data loaded once, queried many times 3. **Scalability**: Handles thousands of events efficiently 4. **Flexibility**: Each structure optimized for its specific use case 5. **Academic Merit**: Demonstrates understanding of data structure trade-offs --- ### Memory vs Database Trade-off: **Pros of In-Memory Structures:** ✅ Lightning-fast lookups ✅ No network latency ✅ Reduced database load ✅ Complex filtering without SQL **Cons:** ❌ Memory usage (acceptable for event data) ❌ Must reload on updates (handled in code) ❌ Not persistent (refreshed from DB) **Verdict:** Perfect for read-heavy operations like event browsing and recommendations. --- ## Video Presentation Tips ### For Prompt 1 (Search Logic): 1. Show the code in your IDE 2. Demonstrate a live search with keyword + category + date 3. Show the SQL query in SQL Server Profiler (optional) 4. Highlight the async/await pattern ### For Prompt 2 (Recommendations): 1. Start with a fresh session (no recommendations) 2. Perform 3-4 searches in the same category 3. Refresh to show personalized recommendations 4. Explain the frequency analysis live ### For Prompt 3 (View Binding): 1. Show the ViewModel class 2. Show the controller building the ViewModel 3.
